In recent years, the methacrolein (MAL) synthesis through the aldol condensation of formaldehyde (FA) with propanal (PA) has received great attention of researchers. Herein, an ionic liquid-functionalized polymer catalyst, which exhibited higher performance than common homogenous sec-amine catalyst, was developed for catalytic synthesis of MAL via aldol condensation of FA with PA. FT-IR, XPS, TG-DTA, and 13C MAS NMR were used to characterize the structural and physicochemical features. The influences of solvent and reaction conditions on the catalytic performance were also systematically studied and optimized. The in situ FT-IR spectroscopic experiments were performed to investigate the catalytic mechanism. Kinetic studies revealed that the activation energy of aldol condensation between the FA and PA was 51.6 kJ/mol. No obvious decay of catalytic performance was observed after twelve cycles. In the process of MMA synthesis, methacrolein (MAL) is a crucial stock which is obtained either by direct oxidative esterification with methanol or by selective oxidation followed by esterification [5-8]. Up to now, there are mainly two methods to produce MAL including selective oxidation of isobutene/isobutane and Mannich reaction between the propanal and formaldehyde catalyzed by sec-amine [9-11], which are displayed in Scheme 1 . Using the Mo-Bi composite compounds as catalyst, Selective oxidation of isobutene and tert-butanol mixture has been applied in industrial production of MAL, and the selectivity can reach 85–89.5 % with a conversion of 92–99.5 %. But the key point in this process is to improve the selectivity and avoid over oxidation [12]. As a consequence, researchers focused more on designing and altering the catalyst's structure to improve selectivity and inhibit adverse reactions. Wang found the Mo-Bi-Co-Fe-Ce-O composite oxides modified by Cs had good catalytic activity in selective oxidation of isobutene to MAL. At the reaction temperature of 360 °C, the Cs element showed a beneficial effect on the catalytic selectivity, giving 87.2 % yield and 72 % selectivity, respectively [13]. Moens used the mixture of α-Bi2Sn2O7 and MoO3 as catalyst and found there were a strong cooperative effects between the α-Bi2Sn2O7 and MoO3, which showed obvious influence on the catalytic activity [14-15]. Other metal oxides and noble metal supported catalysts have also been studied, in addition to the published publications on Mo-Bi catalysts. Liu [16] found that the Re-Sb-O composite compounds showed good catalytic performance on MAL synthesis, and the selectivity and conversion could reach 87 % and 15 % at 350–450 °C. Using a Pt/SbOx catalyst, Inoue produced MAL and discovered that tiny α-Sb2O3 crystallites formed around or on the Pt particles with widely distributed O-SbOy adorning the Pt surface, which prevented the Pt particles from aggregating and over-oxidation of reactant [17]. Although the process of isobutene selective oxidation has been studied intensively, it is still a great challenge to control the selectivity. Recently, the process of the coal-based route has drawn more attention to replacing isobutene selective oxidation, which involves hydroformylating ethylene with CO and H2 to propanal, catalyzed by a rhodium complex, and then aldol condensation of propanal with formaldehyde to create MAL catalyzed by sec-amine or amino-functionalized ionic liquid [18-20]. Compared with the C4 selective oxidation route, high selectivity and yield of MAL can be obtained at a relatively mild reaction. In addition, the feedstock of formaldehyde is cheap and accessible from the coal industry. In order to catch a better understanding on this process, Yan investigated the reaction mechanism through isotopic trace experiments [21]. Additionally, Yan et al. performed a density functional theory calculation to gain insight into the reaction mechanism involved in the formation of MAL from propanal and formaldehyde [22]. The results revealed that the ionic liquid catalyst dramatically decreased the energy barrier in the step of Mannich base decomposition. Despite the homogeneous ionic liquids are effective catalysts for this reaction, problems are still existed in catalyst separation and equipment corrosion [23-25]. Ionic liquid-functionalized polymers or poly ionic liquids emerge as promising alternatives to traditional ionic liquids in various applications, such as esterification, oxidative desulfurization and aldol condensation [26-29]. Wang prepared the copolymer of ionic liquid (3,3′-(butane-1,4-diyl) bis (1-vinyl-1H-imidazol-3-ium)) and diallylamine by ion exchange method for the synthesis of MAL via aldol condensation of formaldehyde with propanal, the selectivity and conversion could reach 99.5 % and 98.7 % [30]. But the catalyst synthesis process is too complicated to scale up. So it is important to find a potential catalyst with high catalytic activity and simple preparation process. The application of ionic liquid-functionalized polymers in synthesis of MAL from formaldehyde and propanal still remains underexplored. In this study, we synthesized a type of ionic liquid-functionalized polymer through grafting diethanolamine onto carboxyl-functionalized polymers via one-step esterification. The impact of various experimental conditions on the catalytic synthesis of MAL from formaldehyde and propanal is thoroughly investigated, as well as the catalytic stability. Additionally, a kinetic model was established for MAL production on this kind of ionic liquid-functionalized polymer. Also, the catalytic mechanism was investigated by in-situ FT-IR. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical reagents The carboxyl functionalized support (S-COOH) with the backbone of copolymer of divinylbenzene and methacrylic acid (D301) was purchased from Hangzhou Lvbao Resin Co. Ltd. The chemical reagents of diethanolamine (DEA, purity, 99.0 %), aluminum trifluoromethanesulfonate (AlTF, purity, 98.0 %) and aqueous formaldehyde solution (FA, purity, 37 %) were supplied by Aladdin Chem. Co. Ltd. China. 1, 4-dioxane (purity, 99.0 %), methanol (purity, 99.5 %), propanal (PA, purity, 97.0 %)and N, N-dimethylformamide (purity, 99.5 %) were gained from Shanghai Macklin Co. Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Before the catalyst preparation, the S-COOH should be thoroughly washed using methanol and dried at 70 °C for 12 h. Then 10 g S-COOH and 2.1 g AlTF were added with 42 g (0.4 mol) DEA in a flask. The mixture was kept at 130 °C for 36 h. The obtained solid powders were filtered from the solution, followed by wash using methanol in a soxhlet extractor and dry at 70 °C for 12 h. Afterwards, the obtained catalyst sample was labeled as S-COOH-DEA. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The physical nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at the temperature of liquid nitrogen were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP2460 system. The specific surface area and pore size distribution were calculated using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. The thermal stability of samples was measured on a Shimadzu TG analyzer in the temperature range increasing from 25 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in the flow of N2. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained on a Nicolet-380 FT-IR spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) using KBr as diluent. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were collected by using an ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) spectrometer with Al Kα radiation at θ = 90° and the C 1S peak at 284.8 eV was used to calibrate the binding energies. The 13C-MAS-NMR characterization was conducted on Bruker AVANCE instrument (500 MHz) with cross-polarization contacting time of 2000 μs loop delay time of 5 s, magic angle tilt of 54.74° and rotor speed of 12,000 Hz. The element analysis (EA) was performed on an Elemental vario EL cube to confirm the content of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and sulfur elements in sample. The density of carboxyl groups was measured by titration method. In a typical process, 0.5 g sample was added into 20 mL NaOH standard solution (1 mol/L) and stirred for 24 h. Then the 0.02 mol/L HCl standard solution was used to determine the density of carboxyl group in the catalyst sample. The pH value was detected by using the pH meter. 2.4 Catalytic activity test The aldol condensation of FA and PA was conducted in a 50 mL flask and the reaction temperature was kept in oil bath under magnetic stirring. Typically, 0.348 g PA, 0.486 g aqueous FA solution, and 5 g DMF solvent were charged in the flask, then 4 g catalyst (with 19.9 mmol active sites) of S-COOH-DEA catalyst is charged into the flask until the required temperature is reached. The reactor is submerged in ice water to quench the reaction after it has finished. The synthesis reaction was conducted under different parameters at the temperature from 60–80 °C, with catalyst amount of 1 g (with 4.97 mmol active sites) to 5 g (with 24.9 mmol active sites), the PA/FA ratio of 0.75–1.25, and reaction time of 5–30 min for process optimization. Prior to the subsequent run, the spent catalyst was cleaned with ethyl acetate and dried at 80 °C, and the catalyst's reusability was assessed under optimal reaction conditions. 2.5 Product analysis After the reaction is completed, the product component was qualitatively and quantitatively analyzed by GC–MS for confirmation of byproducts (Fig. S1) and GC (Agilent 7890) equipped with FID detector and SH-Rtx-Wax column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm), respectively. The 1, 4-dioxane was used as internal standard substrate to quantitatively analyze each component. The catalytic performance can be described by following equations: (1) C PA = n PA 0 − n PA , t n PA 0 × 100 % (2) S MAL = n MAL , t n PA 0 − n PA , t × 100 % (3) Y MAL = C PA × S MAL Where C PA is the conversion of PA, S MAL is the selectivity of MAL, Y MAL is the yield of MAL. The n PA0, n PA, t and n MAL, t are initial molar amount of PA and the molar amount of PA and MAL after t . The content of FA was measured by ultraviolet-visible spectrophotometer using acetylacetone spectrophotometry method. In a buffer solution of acetic acid and ammonium acetate, formaldehyde would form stable complex under heating condition. The formaldehyde content in the cooled solution can be determined at the absorption wavelength of 412 nm. 2.6 Kinetic studies The kinetic experiments were conducted in a 50 mL flask placed in oil bath under magnetic stirring. The reactants with required molar ratio were added in the flask. The catalyst was charged into the flask when the temperature is reached. The rate of MAL formation can be described by Eq. (4). (4) r = d C M A L / d t = k C F A a C P A b Where r is MAL formation rate, C M A L is the concentration of MAL, k is the reaction rate constant, a and b represent the reaction order of PA and FA, C F A and C P A are the concentrations of FA and PA. 2.7 Mechanism investigation The FT-IR spectra were collected on Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 spectrometer equipped with MCT detector. The first specific embodiment involves the place of potassium bromide self-supporting sheets in cell with CaF2 window, and then pretreatment in nitrogen flow at 20 °C (5 mL/min) for the collection of background. The stream containing FA was introduced to the cell by bubbling to record the corresponding standard spectrum of FA. The standard spectra of PA and MAL was collected under the same procedure. After the treatment of stream containing FA for 20 min, the background was recorded. Then, the in situ cell was thoroughly swept by N2 stream. The previous potassium bromide sheet was replaced with catalyst sheet diluted with potassium bromide. The stream containing FA was introduced into in situ cell to observe the change of surface species on catalyst. Afterwards, the stream containing PA was introduced to the in situ cell to identify the formation of intermediates and product MAL. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization S-COOH-DEA is prepared via one-step esterification and its physicochemical properties are identified by different characterization. The FT-IR spectra of DEA, S-COOH and S-COOH-DEA samples are displayed in Fig. 1 a. It can be found that the peaks at 1371 and 3333 cm−1 are attributed to the C-N and N-H bands of DEA [31]. Meanwhile, the intense band at 1053 cm−1 is assigned to the -OH group of DEA. While the characteristic peak at 1713 cm−1 belonged to the vibration of -COOH group of S-COOH and S-COOH-DEA samples. All of these abovementioned characteristic peaks can be found in the spectrum of S-COOH-DEA [32]. In addition, the new peaks appearing at 1005 and 1110 cm−1 can be ascribed to the ester bond of S-COOH-DEA samples, which is derived from the esterification between the DEA and -COOH group in S-COOH [33]. Moreover, the structure of S-COOH-DEA was further measured by the solid-state 13C NMR characterization. As shown in Fig. 1b, the chemical shift at 172.2 ppm is associated with the carboxyl carbon atom in S-COOH and S-COOH-DEA samples. While the chemical shift at 165.2 ppm is attributed to the carbon atom in ester group. The chemical shifts at 70.1 and 44.9 ppm are ascribed to the carbon atom adjacent to the hydroxyl and sec-amino groups of DEA after esterification. The chemical composition and C, O, N species chemical states of S-COOH and S-COOH-DEA are studied by XPS spectra. As shown in Fig. 1c, the peaks at 532.7 and 285.1 eV in the full spectra of S-COOH and S-COOH-DEA samples are related to C 1 s and O 1 s. The peak at 400.1 eV in the full spectrum of S-COOH-DEA is ascribed to the N 1 s. After the esterification between the DEA and carboxyl groups in S-COOH-DEA sample, another two new peaks can be separated at 286.0 and 287.6 eV, which is shown in Fig. 1d. These new characteristic peaks can be ascribed to the formation of ester bond between the DEA and carboxyl groups of S-COOH and C-N bond of DEA [34,35]. As shown in Fig. 1e, the new peak appearing at 530.5 eV is related to the ester bond in S-COOH-DEA sample. In Fig. 1f, the peaks at 401.2 and 399.6 eV are attributed to the -+NH2- and -NH- groups, confirming the successful linkage of DEA with S-COOH via esterification and further internal protonation of sec-amino group by carboxyl group in prepared S-COOH-DEA [36]. Therefore, it can be concluded that the DEA has been successfully grafted onto S-COOH sample through esterification and the sec-amino group is protonated to form the structure of ionic liquid. The element content, porosity and active site density of S-COOH and S-COOH-DEA are determined by physical N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and element analysis, which are shown in Table 1 . The surface area of S-COOH is 2.4 m2/g, however, it decreases to 1.5 m2/g after the graft of DEA through esterification of DEA with the carbonyl group in S-COOH. Moreover, both of the average pore diameter and volume of S-COOH-DEA decrease compared with that of S-COOH. This experimental phenomenon suggests that the linkage of DEA will lead to the decline of pore diameter and volume of S-COOH. It can be found from the element analysis results that the N content of S-COOH-DEA increases obviously compared with that of S-COOH, which also supports the fact that DEA has been linked to S-COOH via esterification. Compared with S-COOH, the carboxyl groups of S-COOH-DEA showed an obvious decline, confirming the DEA has been linked to S-COOH via esterification. According to previous work of our group, the function of carboxyl groups in aldol reaction between FA and PA is promoting the Mannich base decomposition. Considering that the synthesized S-COOH-DEA catalyst will be utilized at thermal condition, it is necessary to test the stability by TG-DTA analysis. As shown in Fig. 2 , the first weight loss presented in TG-DTA curve appears at 100 °C, which is attributed to the removal of surface adsorbed water. The decomposition of S-COOH-DEA begins at 161 °C, which is much higher than the required reaction temperature (80 °C), indicating the S-COOH-DEA is thermally stable during the aldol condensation of PA and FA to produce MAL. 3.2 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic performance of different catalysts on the aldol condensation of PA with FA was examined under certain reaction condition and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . The catalytic activity of S-COOH is much lower than that of S-COOH-DEA, indicating the formation of protonated sec-amino groups after modification plays a key role in the aldol condensation of PA with FA. Besides, the catalytic activity of S-COOH-DEA is very similar to that of diethanolamine acetate ionic liquid. However, the S-COOH-DEA as a heterogeneous catalyst shows the advantage in separation and recycling. So the S-COOH-DEA with the structure of ionic liquid is a potentially excellent catalyst utilized for aldol condensation between the FA and PA compared with the homogeneous diethanolamine acetate. According to the previous study of our group [22], the FA should be activated by the sec-amino group on S-COOH-DEA to form the amino methanol, which then occurs dehydration to form the crucial intermediate of iminium ion. Considering the influence of polarity on the formation of iminium cation and production of water, the solvents with different permittivity were utilized in this aldol condensation and the results are shown in the Table 2 . The yield of MAL increases positively with the permittivity of solvent and the DMF with the highest permittivity of 36.7 exhibits the best performance, which confirms that the polar solvent favors the aldol condensation of PA with FA to produce MAL. The reason can be concluded as following two parts. On one hand, the polar solvent facilitates the desorption of water on the catalyst surface. On the other hand, the reactants of PA and FA show relatively high solubility in the solvent with higher permittivity [37,38]. The reason for the low MAL yield when H2O is used as solvent is that the presence of H2O as a product of this aldol condensation affects the reaction equilibrium and solubility of propanal in aqueous formaldehyde solution, leading to the heavy self-condensation of propanal. Afterwards, the influence of reaction conditions on the catalytic performance was studied and the experiments are performed in the solvent of DMF at 70 °C under the FA/PA ratio of 1:1, as shown in Fig. 4 a. In a low active site amount (4.97 mmol) charged, the conversion of PA was only 30.8 %. With the active site amount in catalytic c system reaching 19.88 mmol, the conversion of PA reaches up to 98.7, and the MAL selectivity is also increased simultaneously. As the synthesis reaction indicated, the side reaction of PA self-condensation is easier to proceed than the cross condensation of PA with FA when is total active site amount is relatively low in the catalytic system. Nonetheless, when the amount of active sites reaches 19.9 mmol, the conversion and selectivity keeps almost unchanged even it is further increased. The effect of reaction temperature as another important factor was assessed in the range of 60–80 °C, and the results were shown in Fig. 4b. With the temperature rising from 60 to 70 °C, the conversion of PA increases significantly, which is beneficial for the selective formation and decomposition of Mannich base. But the selectivity decreases when the temperature is further increased to 80 °C due to the heavy side reactions. Therefore, the optimal reaction temperature is 70 °C. Then the influence of PA/FA molar ratio was evaluated at the temperature of 70 °C under the FA/PA ratio ranging from 0.75:1 to 1:1.25. The conversion and selectivity can be improved by adjusting the molar ratio of reactants, which is due to the competitive adsorption on the catalytic sites and shift of chemical equilibrium. As depicted in Fig. 4c, the PA conversion and MAL selectivity can be enhanced when the ratio of FA to PA changes from 0.75:1 to 1:1. However, both of them keep almost unchanged although the ratio is further increased. So the suitable ratio of FA to PA is 1:1. The effect of reaction time can be found in Fig. 4d that the yield increases sharply from 5 to 25 min. The PA conversion and MAL selectivity climb to the maximum at 25 min. When the reaction time is further extended to 30 min, the PA conversion and MAL selectivity show almost unchanged in comparison with those at 25 min. So the optimal reaction time is 25 min. In summary, the optimal reaction condition is of 19.9 mmol active site amount, 70 °C, PA/FA ratio=1:1 and 25 min reaction time. Under this reaction condition, the conversion of PA and selectivity to MAL are 99.0 % and 97.2 %. In comparison to the other homogeneous catalysts of L-proline and trans-4-hydroxy-L-proline, the S-COOH-DEA shows similar catalytic activity with the advantages in recovery and recycling. To identify the corresponding characteristic peaks of reactants and product, the FT-IR spectra of FA, PA, MAL are recorded as displayed in Fig. S3. To be more specific, the in situ FT-IR spectroscopic experiments were carried out in the stream containing FA to identify the formation of amino methanol produced from the condensation of FA with the sec-amino group on catalyst. After that, the in situ cell is swept out with N2 flow, and the previous potassium bromide sheet is replaced with catalyst pellet diluted with potassium bromide. The related spectra are exhibited in Fig. 7 . The new peak emerging at 1343 cm−1 can be attributed to the vibration of characteristic C-N bond of amino methanol (Fig. 7a), which gradually becomes intense [42]. Then the PA is subsequently introduced to the cell to observe the generation of Mannich base intermediate and product MAL. As displayed in Fig. 7 b, the peak at 1382 cm−1, which is assigned to the C-N bond of Mannich base, can be observed after the introduction of PA, indicating the formation of Mannich base [43]. Meanwhile, the peak at 1746 cm−1 is related to the C=O bonds of PA, and these two peaks at 1701 and 1672 cm−1 are assigned to the C=O and C=C bonds of MAL (Fig. 7c). The mechanism of aldol condensation between the FA and PA is proposed in Fig. 8 on the basis of characterization results and previous study [22]. Firstly, the sec-amino group of S-COOH-DEA is attacked by FA to form the amino methanol intermediate. Secondly, the amino methanol transforms to the iminium ion via dehydration. Then the condensation of iminium ion with the enolized PA after protonation proceeds to form the Mannich base. Finally, the Mannich base decomposes to MAL through the proton transfer and C-N bond break. 3.5 Catalytic stability To examine the catalytic stability of S-COOH-DEA, the durable experiments are conducted under the optimal reaction condition. It can be seen from Fig. 9 a that the PA conversion and MAL selectivity keep almost unchanged after 12 recycling. Thus, the S-COOH-DEA can be considered as a stable catalyst for MAL synthesis through aldol condensation between the FA and PA. Then the FT-IR and element analysis of spent catalyst was performed and compared with those of fresh catalyst. The FT-IR spectra indicate that the skeleton structure of S-COOH-DEA catalyst was unchanged after twelve runs (Fig. 9b). The contents of C, N and H elements in the spent catalyst are 49.5 wt%, 6.76 wt% and 9.18wt%, which are similar to the fresh sample. 4 Conclusion In this paper, an ionic liquid functionalized polymer is prepared through esterification between the DEA and carboxyl group in S-COOH as catalyst for the MAL synthesis over aldol condensation between the FA and PA. The catalytic performance of prepared catalyst is almost the same to that of homogenous diethanolamine acetate ionic liquid, proving that this kind of catalyst is a good substitute for the homogeneous sec-amine type catalyst. The polarity of solvent can significantly affect the catalytic performance and DMF with the highest permittivity shows the best performance. The reaction conditions including the total active site amount, FA/PA ratio, reaction temperature and reaction time on the reaction process are evaluated. Under the optimal reaction condition, the conversion of PA can reach 99.0 %, with the selectivity of 97.6 %. The mechanism investigation shows that the amino methanol and Mannich base are the crucial intermediates during the aldol condensation of PA with FA to produce MAL. No deactivation behavior is found for the S-COOH-DEA after twelve times recycling. The kinetic studies reveal that the activation energy of aldol condensation between the FA and PA was calculated as 51.6 kJ/mol. coredata.dc:description: In recent years, the methacrolein (MAL) synthesis through the aldol condensation of formaldehyde (FA) with propanal (PA) has received great attention of researchers. Herein, an ionic liquid-functionalized polymer catalyst, which exhibited higher performance than common homogenous sec-amine catalyst, was developed for catalytic synthesis of MAL via aldol condensation of FA with PA. FT-IR, XPS, TG-DTA, and 13C MAS NMR were used to characterize the structural and physicochemical features. The influences of solvent and reaction conditions on the catalytic performance were also systematically studied and optimized. The in situ FT-IR spectroscopic experiments were performed to investigate the catalytic mechanism. Kinetic studies revealed that the activation energy of aldol condensation between the FA and PA was 51.6 kJ/mol. No obvious decay of catalytic performance was observed after twelve cycles.
